Comment: There's not really an objective way to do this. "Clean" is a relative term. If a river was horribly polluted, and now it's 20% less polluted, but still 80% polluted, is that success or failure? Depends who you ask. Even if a bill is 100% successful, in that it cleans all the pollutants noticed and named in the bill, it may still be missing something. For example, there was a time plastic was celebrated as a way to use LESS paper and therefore be MORE environmentally friendly...and now that just seems laughably stupid. And how far back are we looking? Should we do a retrospective in 5 years, or 10 years, or 15 years? Our energy grid infrastructure has been much talked about as failing now, 60 years or more since it was built. Should we look back 60 years on policies? The Colorado River water allocation laws were made in the 1800s. How do we know when is the "definitive" look on how successful a policy was?  Answering the questions you're trying to answer requires an argument. It requires someone taking up a question in as much depth as is sufficient to answer the question, with as much time past as is relevant, repeated as many times as is necessary. This cannot be something we do in a systematic, objective fashion. The good news is, this is exactly what books are really good at, and there are plenty of authors that do take deep dives into policy issues like this.  High-quality newspapers are also good at doing this, though obviously you're subject to the topics they want to discuss. But for example, NYT ran an article a couple months ago about the huge progress the US has made in the last few decades regarding child poverty, and then discussed the reasons for those results. It was a fantastic article, but if you don't really care that much about the issue of child poverty, then you're still stuck waiting for whatever you do want to look at.
